messageBody:
[JBR]
...Agreed, and so using nested classes for related fixtures is not a bad
idea at all. I just don't think that it's necessarily any clearer: it's
just all in one file rather than in three.





Your points are good, but they seem to boil down to having several
different classes with good names and all will be right with the world.
While that may be true, the problem I have is more at the package scope.
When looking at a directory, how do you know where to start looking? The
reason I like the inner classes is that you can set up a test suite of
sorts in an obviously named class. With those inner classes, you can
still have several test files that support that main one, but if you are
entering a directory to investigate someone else's testing strategy,
then having a well-defined starting point is a great help. Don't get me
wrong, you can still use several different files, so long as they are
referenced from within an obviously named one. Using your Bag examples,
I would say that the BagTest should refer to the other two, and possibly
a third that actually has the run-of-the-mill type tests. That way, when
entering a directory with tests for 20 or more classes (look at
java.util for example), I could find BagTest.java quickly and from there
discover the other test classes that are directly applicable.



Granted, this is all beginning to sound like the student teaching the
teacher, but while I lack some JUnit experience, the software
engineering experience is there. One of the hardest things about
approaching a body of source code (production or test) is figuring out
where to start. To that end, it seems having a single, well-named
starting point makes great strides.



Josh
